title: JetBlue Trims Flights Through Mid-January as Omicron, Weather Challenge Airlines
summary: Carrier scrubs about 1,280 flights through Jan. 13; fast, high-altitude winds speed some travelers, slow others. JetBlue Airways Corp. said it would trim its schedule through mid-January as more of its crews are sickened by the latest coronavirus variant.

title: Biden Administration Asks Supreme Court to Consider Its Bid to End 'Remain in Mexico' Policy
summary: Legal setbacks have forced the administration to continue the Trump-era immigration program. WASHINGTON-The Biden administration Wednesday asked the Supreme Court to consider its bid to end the Trump-era "Remain in Mexico" immigration policy, following legal setbacks that have forced the government to continue the program.

title: U.S. Hit With Record Number of New Covid-19 Cases
summary: Infections surge as health officials expect the Omicron variant to keep spreading. Covid-19 cases in the U.S. have continued to climb, reaching a pandemic record on Tuesday of 265,427 cases a day on average, according to a Wall Street Journal analysis of Johns Hopkins University data.

title: Didi's Revenue Falls After Beijing's Crackdown Hurts Its China Business
summary: The ride-hailing company's China mobility business-which includes its core ride-hailing operations-was the main cause for the drop. Didi Global Inc. said Wednesday its third-quarter revenues dropped 11.5% from the preceding three months, after Chinese regulators launched a cybersecurity probe into the ride-hailing firm and forced many of its apps to be taken down.

title: Ghislaine Maxwell Found Guilty in Sex-Trafficking Case
summary: Verdict caps yearslong effort to seek justice for Jeffrey Epstein's accusers. British socialite Ghislaine Maxwell was found guilty Wednesday on five of six criminal counts in her sex-trafficking case, capping federal prosecutors' push to bring the longtime confidante of disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein to justice.

title: Biden Takes Detroit for a Ride
summary: The car makers get new fuel standards but may not get electric-vehicle subsidies.. Political theater can be more entertaining than what's on TV. It's hard not to get a chuckle watching auto makers get double-crossed by the Biden Administration after they worked so hard to promote its electric-vehicle agenda.

title: Beijing Courts the Solomon Islands
summary: Turning from the West, the Pacific state accepts Chinese police support.. The 1942 Battle of Guadalcanal proved the critical importance of the Solomon Islands for Pacific security. China's rulers have studied this history. As Beijing seeks to displace the U.S. as the dominant power in the Pacific, it's establishing a small police presence on the Solomon Islands that could easily grow. This development underscores the importance of U.S. engagement with the small but strategic sovereign states dotting the world's largest ocean.

title: The CDC Sees a Great Covid Light
summary: The shorter isolation period balances public health and the economy.. 'Tis the season for epiphanies, even at the White House. President Biden on Monday said there's no "federal solution" to the pandemic, and now his Administration is acknowledging that protecting public health requires balancing social and economic considerations.

title: No One Is Safe in Hong Kong
summary: Authorities extend their assault on anyone who dissents from the Communist Party line.. China's shredding of Hong Kong's autonomy is reaching new levels of nastiness. This week authorities forced the closure of the online publication Stand News and levied new charges against Apple Daily executives.

title: S&P 500's Energy Sector on Pace to Hit Record Growth
summary: The energy sector, battered by pandemic shutdowns in 2020, bounces back. The S&P 500 index's energy sector is on pace for the biggest percentage gain on record, marking a comeback for a sector hard hit by early pandemic shutdowns.

title: When It Comes to Inflation, I'm Still on Team Transitory
summary: Fed Chair Powell may have retired the term, but bottlenecks and shortages should be over soon.. Inflation was a Grinch this Christmas. Economists on Team Transitory, myself included, should admit that we never thought inflation would go this high. What happened? Does high inflation still look transitory?

title: I Got a Lot Right in 2021, but I Overestimated Biden
summary: As for 2022, the GOP will retake Congress, and Covid will fade in political significance.. It's time to tally my right and wrong predictions for 2021 and offer fresh prognostications for the New Year. The split was 17½ right to 7½ wrong. This 70% accuracy sounds adequate-but when I was wrong, I was really wrong.

title: The Religious Roots of Turkey's Currency Crisis
summary: Erdogan's adherence to the Quran's commandment prohibiting paying interest on money is destroying the lira's value.. As Turkey's economy heads into a tailspin because of the collapse of its currency, the lira, investors and economists wonder why President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has continued the eccentric economic policy that caused this crisis. He has made clear that his motivation is primarily religious.

title: 'Let's Go Brandon' and Other Codes
summary: Disney World refers to a troublemaker as a 'treasured guest.'. Staff at Disney World refer to a troublemaker as a "treasured guest." A "Code Winnie" alert means someone urinated in the pool.

title: Victoria's Secret Shares Rise on Buyback Plan, Holiday Sales
summary: The lingerie chain, spun off from L Brands in August, plans to repurchase $250 million of its own shares. Shares of Victoria's Secret & Co. soared Wednesday after the lingerie seller said it plans to buy back $250 million of its own shares and reported strong sales growth during the holidays.

title: No, Joe Biden Didn't Save Christmas
summary: Millions of American workers saved a complex economy from buckling.. It's hard to say whose comments I look forward to more-the president of the United States or presidential explainer Jen Psaki. The two bring to mind a great line of Sydney Greenstreet's fat criminal Kasper Gutman in "The Maltese Falcon": "By gad, sir, you are a character. There's never any telling what you'll say or do next, except that it's bound to be something astonishing."

title: Notable & Quotable: 14 Days to Slow the Spread
summary: 'The so-called circuit breakers would be triggered once individual regions have met or are approaching certain thresholds of COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations.'. Amanda Kaufmanreporting for the Boston Globe, Dec. 27:

title: 'Tractor Wars' Review: American Power Pull
summary: The farm tractor wasn't born overnight. Perfecting it led to a three-way battle between Ford, John Deere and International Harvester.. When one thinks of Henry Ford, one thinks of automobiles. The visionary engineer and entrepreneur all but invented the auto industry when he founded the Ford Motor Co. in 1903. Five years later he manufactured the first affordable car for middle-class Americans, the Model T, having first devised the assembly-line process to mass produce this epoch-making innovation.

title: Google and Rivals Tap Cash to Excel in Cloud
summary: Alphabet company and others invest in potential clients as they look to close gap with Amazon in fast-growing sector. Google and its rivals are wielding a new weapon in the battle for cloud-computing market share: big-dollar investments in companies that agree to sign on to their services.

title: S&P 500, Dow Edge Higher to Records
summary: Investors' subsiding fears over the Omicron variant have helped propel stocks higher in recent sessions. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed to fresh records Wednesday in a choppy session exacerbated by light holiday trading volumes.

title: Sam Cooke: Blues Master and Conceptual Pioneer
summary: With records like 'Tribute to the Lady' and 'My Kind of Blues,' the singer left an indelible mark on the musical landscape..

title: 'The Regional' Review: The Midwest on the Move
summary: A survey of contemporary art from an often neglected part of the U.S. is an important reminder that there's plenty of creativity between the coasts. Cincinnati

title: Judge Rejects Oklahoma's Bid to Halt Vaccine Mandate for National Guard
summary: Federal judge denies injunction request by governor, state attorney general and others. A federal judge has rejected Oklahoma's attempt to halt a coronavirus vaccine mandate for its National Guard members, in a test of the federal government's ability to require shots.

title: Calendar Boxes (Thursday Crossword, December 29)
SpaceX Project's FAA Review Delayed by Two Months
summary: Environmental review is one part of commercial space licensing process for facility in Boca Chica, Texas. Federal regulators have delayed the release of an environmental review of SpaceX's plan to launch a new rocket from Texas by two months. One of the reasons? Too many comments from the public.

title: Biden, Putin to Talk Amid Ukraine Crisis
summary: Call will be second by the leaders this month and comes as Russia continues a military buildup near Ukraine and issues sweeping security demands. President Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin plan to talk Thursday ahead of high-level negotiations to deal with what one senior U.S. official described as a "moment of crisis" over Russia's military buildup near Ukraine.

title: Biggest U.S. Egg Producer Hurt by Feed, Labor Costs
summary: Cal-Maine Foods reports lackluster earnings, sending shares down. Shares in Cal-Maine Foods Inc. fell as much as 8% in early trading Wednesday after the egg producer posted lower-than-expected quarterly earnings, hurt by rising feed and labor costs.

title: 10 Letters to Read: December's Most Notable Letters to the Editor
summary: A selection of contributions by readers from Queens, N.Y., to Eagle, Idaho; from sports media in Nashville to the regime in Hong Kong..

title: Who Wants to Solve the Student Loan Crisis?
summary: Biden freezes payments without even attempting to address the bad incentives at the root of the issue.. "The Forever Student Loan Emergency" (Review & Outlook, Dec. 23) shows there's more than one way to skin a taxpayer. Recurring White House fiats for suspension of student loan payments, without accrual of interest, is a nifty alternative to not-yet-passable legislation that permanently cancels most or all of the $1.6 trillion in debt. The slow drip out of Treasury-and ultimately taxpayer pockets-is more palatable than wiping $1 trillion off the books in one fell swoop with legislation that forgives as much as $50,000 in debt per student.

title: Christmas vs. Communism, Poland 1981
summary: Toilet paper was in such short supply that it could not be left in bathroom stalls.. Thomas Swick's "Christmas in Communist Poland" (op-ed, Dec. 24) brings back memories of my first trip to Warsaw, Christmas week, 1981. I was new to my job as head of First Chicago's Eastern European office. My boss accompanied me to introduce me to our three Polish customers, the only three banks in the country.

title: Evaluating Lockdowns From 1918 to the Present
summary: 'Rapid implementation of multiple NPIs can significantly reduce influenza transmission' until the measures are relaxed.. Regarding Phillip Magness and Peter Earle's op-ed "The Fickle 'Science' of Lockdowns" (Dec. 20): A 2007 article in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences reanalyzed the 1918 Spanish flu data. Those cities that early on implemented multiple nonpharmaceutical interventions (NPIs), including school, church and theater closings, as well as bans on public gatherings, had peak death rates approximately 50% lower than those that did not.

title: No More U.S. Help for China
summary: We fed the bear that now wants to consume us.. Thomas Duesterberg's "The Slow Meltdown of The Chinese Economy" (op-ed, Dec. 21) is rare and welcome information. But his final thought that China in distress might be helped by the U.S. is unwise.

title: Philly Voters Asked for This
summary: DA Larry Krasner was re-elected in November, amid the uptick in crime.. Your editorial "A Larry Krasner Christmas" (Dec. 23) lets the voters of Philadelphia off too easy. Mr. Krasner was re-elected in November, amid the uptick in crime. The violence is a result of the policies pursued not only by the district attorney, but also the city council and mayor. Until the voters hold their representatives accountable, things will continue to deteriorate.

title: What to Watch: Five Movies and Shows to Stream
summary: Resume Subscription. Two women are brought together by the challenges of motherhood in "The Lost Daughter," rivals unite against a common enemy in "Cobra Kai," and the Harry Potter trio is back together for a reunion. Plus, "The Book of Boba Fett" enters the Star Wars universe.

title: Record-Setting Buyer Strikes Again in Aspen With $44.5 Million Buy
summary: Hockey player-turned-entrepreneur Patrick Dovigi, who spent $72.5 million in June on a compound nearby, adds a 3.5-acre, six-bedroom property to his real estate portfolio. A property in Aspen, Colo., has closed for $44.5 million in an off-market deal, according to Pitkin County records. The property has views of downtown Aspen and ski slopes.

title: Northvolt Develops Lithium-Ion Battery Cell, a First for European Company
summary: Swedish battery maker plans to deliver batteries to customers in 2022. Swedish battery maker Northvolt said Wednesday it created a lithium-ion battery cell, the first by a European company, and plans to ship it to companies to power electric vehicles next year.

title: Grinch Bots Steal Christmas Again
summary: Supply-chain issues and an increase in online sales are proving to be a gift for bad bots. Grinch bots are putting some grift into gifts.

title: Stop Making Small Talk. No One Will Miss It.
summary: A behavioral economist answers questions about chatting with strangers and writing thank-you notes for gifts.. Behavioral economist Dan Ariely uses psychological research to advise on everyday dilemmas. Read more columns here.

title: New Challenges Hit the Defense Business
summary: Military stocks are doing poorly amid new competition from outside the industry and changes in spending, procurement. Investors have lost something of their awe for the U.S. military industrial complex. In an era when the Pentagon is prioritizing new technologies and opening its doors to Silicon Valley firms, legacy contractors can look a bit stuffy-even if they keep getting tons of cash.

title: The Doctor's Office Becomes an Assembly Line
summary: Consolidation is wiping out private practices and making medical care costlier and worse.. Since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic, my dad's rheumatology practice has been flooded with new patients, including many from far-flung cities or out of state. This isn't thanks to a new marketing strategy or to a notable spike in arthritis sufferers. One elderly woman who had traveled from New Jersey to my father's Brooklyn, N.Y., office explained that many practices near her home had closed. Those that remained open were so overwhelmed that she would have had to wait eight months for an appointment.

title: No Democracy Should Participate in the 2022 Beijing Olympics
summary: The Chinese Communist Party tries to whitewash its image in preparation for the Winter Games.. In advance of the 2022 Olympics this February, the Chinese Communist Party is on a campaign to whitewash its image. Plastering over the ever-growing list of human-rights abuses-including the takeover of Hong Kong, the internment of Muslims in Xinjiang, the disappearance of tennis star Peng Shuai, the Covid coverup and threats to democratic Taiwan-the party wields denial, obfuscation and cash. The latest campaign pushes the absurd claim that China enjoys democratic government at home while deriding as undemocratic the world's real democracies.

title: Travel Startups Say Omicron Disruptions Create Opportunities
summary: People are so eager to travel that after the new Covid-19 variant led customers to cancel trips abroad, many booked U.S. vacations instead, says the CEO of travel agency Fora. Americans are taking their vacations, despite the rise in Covid-19 cases caused by the Omicron variant. But they want greater flexibility and are taking more precautions, which is benefiting startups that aim to help people navigate the new realities of pandemic travel.

title: A California Couple Spent Eight Years Building Their Dream Retirement Home in Costa Rica
summary: Resume Subscription. Joe and Julia Roberson spent eight years building a dream retirement home on top of a mountain overlooking the ocean in Costa Rica. Then, last May, they made an abrupt shift, and bought a move-in ready house in a golf club community in South Carolina.

title: Turkish Lira Resumes Slide Days After Government Rescue Plan
summary: The currency fell more than 6% against the dollar, undoing part of its significant comeback since last week. Turkey's currency tumbled against the dollar Wednesday, a setback to the government's experimental plan to stabilize the currency.

title: A Master Penny-Pincher Draws a Following in Japan
summary: Megumi Nakano offers daily tips on Instagram about how not to spend money. Half a radish is put to good use.. TOKYO-On a recent afternoon, Megumi Nakano signed copies of her book for some of her 117,000 Instagram followers, who oohed and aahed at seeing her in the flesh.

title: Facebook's Pushback: Stem the Leaks, Spin the Politics, Don't Say Sorry
summary: Resume Subscription. The day after former Facebook employee and whistleblower Frances Haugen went public in October, the company's team in Washington started working the phones.

title: Top Colleges in the South by Size
summary: Davidson, Duke and North Carolina stand out in the WSJ/THE College Rankings. Davidson College is the top small school in the South in the Wall Street Journal/Times Higher Education College Rankings, with Duke University ranked highest among the region's midsize schools and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill its top large school.

title: A Thoroughly Modern but Cozy Mountain Cabin
summary: An airy Catskills getaway is all comfort, with nary a camp cliché in sight. "RUSTIC YET refined." This was the aesthetic goal of New York City firms NevelHaus Development and INC Architecture & Design when they began designing and building their contemporary Catskills cabins. The homes would be woodsy country houses for sophisticated design consumers escaping the city, said Adam Rolston, creative director and managing partner at INC. The first of the 19 sustainable residences in New York's Sullivan and Ulster counties went to Broadway musical "Hamilton" star Phillipa Soo and her actor husband Steven Pasquale.

title: As Omicron Spreads, States Aim for Balance Between Curbs and Safety
summary: Governments seek to avoid strict measures of previous Covid-19 surges, with more vaccinations and rapid tests and by tracking hospitalizations. As states grapple with how to rein in the spreading Omicron variant, many governors and health officials are applying a lighter touch than during previous Covid-19 surges, as they are armed with more tools to combat the virus and increasingly mindful of the economic harm caused by sweeping restrictions.

title: Deutsche Bank Fined for Weak Controls on Rate Data
summary: Germany's financial regulator BaFin said the bank didn't do enough to tighten controls after $3.5 billion in earlier fines related to rate rigging. Deutsche Bank AG was fined nearly $10 million by Germany's financial regulator on Wednesday for not having strong enough controls around data submissions that help set a European interest-rate benchmark.

title: The Supply-Chain Crunch Is Like a Traffic Jam
summary: A congested roadway can be eased by creative detours, something that companies are doing to fix their logistical problems. -Additional design and development by Kara Dapena and Danny Dougherty.

title: Covid-19, Inflation Make a Mess Out of Predictions
summary: Polarized ideology robs leaders, voters of the flexibility needed to cope with the unexpected. Every year the World Economic Forum asks business, political and thought leaders to rank the biggest risks in the coming year or two. At the start of 2020, infectious disease didn't make the list. Covid-19 became the most disruptive pandemic in a century. At the start of this year, inflation didn't make the list either. It is now the most vexing problem in the U.S. economy.

title: Government Tests Novel Legal Strategy Against Jan. 6 Rioters
summary: As first trials approach, some defendants are challenging use of Sarbanes-Oxley Act to obtain felony convictions, stiff sentences. WASHINGTON-The U.S. criminal investigation into the Jan. 6 Capitol riot is entering a more contentious phase as it nears the one-year mark, with initial trials set to test the government's strategy of using provisions first laid out in a 2002 financial-industry law to prosecute some accused of leading the mob.

title: Harry Potter and the Children Whose Parents Named Them After Wizards
summary: From Albus to Draco, Harry Potter fans named their children after characters of the beloved series. We asked them and their kids how that turned out.. Hermione Marshall, a British teenager who works in a flower shop, was named after the heroine of the Harry Potter books and films. A 6-year-old in Ohio shares his name with Ollivander, the magical wandmaker from the series. Venerable wizard Albus Dumbledore has a namesake-a second-grader from Las Vegas who loves a good outer-space joke.

title: Pandemic Gives New Hope to One of the World's Fastest-Shrinking Countries
summary: Resume Subscription. SOFIA, Bulgaria-When Nicko Aleksiev left this city for France, in 2011, he didn't expect he would ever live in Bulgaria again.

title: Self-Care Strategies for Burned Out Caregivers
summary: Resume Subscription. After another brutal year of caregiving, Denise Brown learned what she needed most and now offers that lesson to others.

title: Hormel's Departing CFO on His Career, Deal Making and the Pandemic
summary: Jim Sheehan this year struck a deal to acquire Planters from Kraft Heinz for over $3 billion. He is retiring after 43 years with Hormel.. Jim Sheehan joined Hormel Foods Corp. , the Austin, Minn.-based maker of Spam, in 1978 and over the years saw its product portfolio expand to include nonmeat products such as Skippy peanut butter.

title: Battle at Printing-Press Maker Shows Difficulty of Japan Takeovers
summary: After Supreme Court backs poison-pill plan against 'aggressive interloper,' foreign investors say takeover rules need clarifying. TOKYO-Global investors including Warren Buffett have identified Japan as a market packed with undervalued companies. But a recent case in which management used a poison pill to stop an aggressive share buyer-with the Supreme Court's endorsement-shows why newcomers have a tough time unlocking Tokyo's opportunities.

title: John Madden Made Football a Moment
summary: How a coaching phenom took to the booth, and revolutionized the sport he adored. John Madden was the coach next door.

title: Eric Adams Courts Business as He Prepares to Become NYC Mayor Jan. 1
summary: The Democrat is meeting with business leaders and working with aides of former Mayor Michael Bloomberg. As Eric Adams prepares to become mayor of New York City Jan. 1, he has been reaching out to local business leaders in the first signs of what executives say they hope will be an administration more focused on economic development and law enforcement than that of Mayor Bill de Blasio.

title: In Southeast Asia, Politics Are a Family Affair
summary: Political dynasties are rising to power and broadening their reach in the Philippines, Indonesia and Cambodia. Political dynasties are increasingly dominating governments in Southeast Asia, posing an obstacle to good governance in one of the world's most economically vibrant regions.

title: Should Retailers Split E-Commerce From Stores?
summary: Saks.com CEO and a former chief of Best Buy present views on a strategy some investors are pushing. Macy's Inc. and Kohl's Corp. have recently come under pressure from different investors to split off their e-commerce businesses. The activist push follows a decision by the owner of Saks Fifth Avenue in early 2021 to do just that.

title: The Metaverse Isn't Ready for You, but Your Investment Is Welcome
summary: It could pay off, much like the purchase of land in Manhattan 250 years ago. In a 24-hour experiment with a virtual reality headset, Wall Street Journal personal tech columnist Joanna Stern described the metaverse last month as fractured, freaky, sometimes frightening, but also kind of fun. All in a (virtual) day's work, she traveled, exercised and played games. As a "legless torso that glides as a ghost," she even met with her editor. In real life, she nursed a headache.

title: Hong Kong Stocks on Track for Worst Year in a Decade
summary: Pummeled by China's regulatory crackdowns, the Hang Seng Index is among the world's worst-performing major markets in 2021. Stocks in Hong Kong have taken a battering in 2021, with China's regulatory crackdowns helping to put the city's flagship equity index on course for its biggest loss in a decade.

title: Drugmakers Battle Over Patents for Covid-19 Vaccines
summary: Resume Subscription. A high-stakes legal battle is taking shape over lucrative patent rights for Covid-19 vaccines, with drug companies pitted against each other and government and academic scientists over who invented what.

title: Amazon Turnover Presents Challenge for Union Organizers
summary: High churn rate limits the union's ability to gain a foothold with employees. As organizers prepare for a second unionization election at an Amazon.com Inc. warehouse in Alabama, one of the most significant challenges they face is the possibility that many people employed at the facility now may not be there when the vote is held.

title: Surfside Condo Collapse: From Glimmering Beaches to Ruin
summary: Resume Subscription. SURFSIDE, Fla.-In 2017, Abraham Topp and his brother took over the Champlain Towers South condo where their parents had lived happily for two decades on an idyllic stretch of beach-and quickly found signs of trouble.

title: IPOs' Record Year Ends on Low Note for Most Newcomers
summary: Threats of higher rates are driving down prices of high-growth stocks; two-thirds of 2021 IPOs now sit below their offer prices. Looming behind a record-breaking run for IPOs in 2021 is a darker truth: After a selloff in high-growth stocks during the waning days of the year, two-thirds of the companies that went public in the U.S. this year are now trading below their IPO prices.

title: Face Money Fears for a Happier Financial Life
summary: Research suggests that seeking more insight on complex money issues could positively affect a person's overall happiness. Improving your financial life can sometimes feel like a Catch-22: The same money issue you need to unsnarl creates so much anxiety that you end up turning away from it altogether.

title: Hong Kong Pro-Democracy Site Stand News Closes After Arrests, Raid
summary: Resume Subscription. HONG KONG-National security police in Hong Kong arrested seven people linked to the popular pro-democracy news site Stand News, prompting it to shut down and dealing a further blow to freedom of speech in a city once celebrated for its rambunctious journalism.

title: Chinese AI Giant SenseTime's IPO Comes at a Bad Time
summary: SenseTime has developed strong AI technology. Next, it needs to figure out how to make money from it.. China's SenseTime has overcome headwinds to go public. Its next challenge is to find a path to profit.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.
